awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Distributed Data-Sharing for Fast Response and Decision Support
awd_abstract_narration:
The vision of a smart city is underpinned by its ability to collect, manage, and use data. However, data access remains a fundamental challenge across city agencies, public institutions, and community stakeholders. This project is championing a paradigm shift in data sharing by implementing a new data access framework that allows users to share access to data in-situ instead of sending copies of data around. This project builds on the new data access paradigm to deploy a city Data Access Network (City-DAN) to support city managers get timely access to important data for fast decision and response. City-DAN is piloted first in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam and then scaled to other ASEAN cities.  This activity is in response to NSF Dear Colleague Letter Supporting Transition of Research into Cities through the US ASEAN ((Association of Southeast Asian Nations Cities) Smart Cities Partnership in collaboration with NSF and the US State Department.  The research team (University of Virginia) is working closely with stakeholders in Ho Chi Minh City including city managers, departments, and community organizers as well as Vietnam National University – International University to transition technology into practice.

The proposed distributed, peer-to-peer data access framework represents an ambitious vision of the next generation data ecosystem. This project establishes a foundational data platform to underpin smart cities by addressing issues of data integrity, provenance, control, and timely access. This project takes advantage of the unique deployment opportunity to pursue a vibrant research agenda on grid computing. Specific research areas include advanced cyber infrastructure, cybersecurity, networking, and persistent identifiers. This project will especially focus on identity and access management (IAM) in the context of unreliable infrastructure and weak level-of-assurance (identify proofing) baselines. The project will examine new approaches for enhancing reliability while balancing with transparency and QoS. Lessons learned also can be adopted to advance the smart and connected community research community in the US and other countries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Flooding is one of the most pervasive and costly natural hazards facing urban environments worldwide. In rapidly developing regions, such as those across Southeast Asia, weak infrastructure, coupled with high population density and climate volatility, magnifies the frequency and impact of floods. Designed to address this urgent need, our team of researchers have developed a system, reffered to as FloodWatch, set out with a dual purpose: to create a robust, next-generation data-sharing platform capable of collecting and analyzing varied data streams in near real time, and to apply that platform to a high-impact use case of urban flood monitoring and early warning.

To meet its ambitious vision, the project fused multiple technological layers. The research team integrated diverse data sources ranging from weather sensors and crowd-sourced images to time-series data on water levels into a cloud-based analytics pipeline that enables flexible, near-real-time applications. The core intellectual contributions include:

(1) Novel Data Infrastructure and Analytics: Researchers built a modular, globally accessible data infrastructure incorporating IoT devices, machine learning, and an open-ended analytics engine. This framework accelerates scientific exploration of urban flooding through data-driven predictions (e.g., an neural network-based flood severity index) while remaining adaptable for other domains (e.g., air-quality monitoring).

(2)  Automated Validation of Crowd-Sourced Data: A hybrid approach combining a Convolutional Neural Network classifier with real-time weather feeds was developed to validate user-submitted flood images. This innovation extends to other big-data scenarios that require automated content validation.

(3) Multi-City Deployment: FloodWatch was piloted not just in Vietnam (Ho Chi Minh City, Danang, and other sites) but also extended to Charlottesville (USA) and Cote d Azur (France). These testbeds informed technical enhancements to network reliability, data ingestion pipelines, and cross-platform scalability.

(4) Peer-Reviewed Publications & Patent: The project team produced peer-reviewed publications in premier venues (e.g., IEEE, ACM, AAAI) and filed a patent (PCT/US2024/37704) related to the CNN-based flood-image validation system.

An equally significant pillar of FloodWatch is its commitment to community collaboration and capacity-building. Collaborations with local partners in Vietnam, the United States, and France have laid the groundwork for larger-scale adoption, including pilot deployments in multiple cities and ongoing discussions to integrate FloodWatch into official municipal operations. FloodWatch focuses on improving urban resilience to flooding, building international research collaborations, and training a diverse cohort of young scientists and engineers. This collaborative approach led to broader impacts on multiple aspects:

(1) Enhanced Public Safety & Urban Resilience: By delivering near-real-time flood forecasts and risk maps through a user-friendly interface, the system provides actionable information for residents, local governments, and emergency responders, ultimately reducing community vulnerability to floods.

(2) Community Engagement & Cultural Exchange: Collaborations with local maker spaces, municipal agencies (e.g., Danang Intelligent Operations Center), and universities (in Vietnam, the U.S., and Europe) fostered cross-cultural partnerships, including symposiums (ISSCEI) that drew over 80 participants to discuss sustainable urban technologies.

(3) Workforce Development & Student Training: Over the course of the project, dozens of undergraduates and graduate students (from both U.S. and overseas institutions) gained hands-on experience in IoT, data analytics, software engineering, and field deployment. Several graduated to top-tier tech industry roles or prestigious graduate programs, strengthening the global pipeline of STEM talent.

(4) Technology Transfer & Sustainability: Partnerships with the University of Virginia Licensing and Venture Group led to a full patent application and potential commercialization pathways. Ongoing collaborations with international research centers (e.g., the Asian Water Research Center in Ho Chi Minh City) further ensure that FloodWatch remains active, sustainable, and primed for broader adoption across other ASEAN regions and beyond.

Looking forward, FloodWatch trajectory remains promising. Continued expansion through new sensor deployments, deeper integration with municipal dashboards, and enhanced predictive models will refine and extend the platform capabilities. Partnerships with entities like the Asian Water Research Center (CARE) in Ho Chi Minh City and the UVA Licensing and Ventures Group point toward an enduring, multi-stakeholder approach to technology transfer and commercialization. By demonstrating that low-cost sensing, AI-driven data validation, and multi-modal analytics can be integrated into an accessible, globally distributed pipeline, the FloodWatch project paves the way for broader applications that address not just flooding but the complex spectrum of issues confronting modern cities.
